text.p: Nepal's Foreign Minister Prakash Chandra Lohani said on Wednesday he had resigned from his post in protest against what he described as "widespread rigging and intimidation" by the country's main communist party in recent local elections.
Lohani belongs to Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur Chand's Rashtriya Prajatantra Party (RPP).
The voting on May 17 and 26 for nearly 190,000 representatives in 4,000 village committees and 58 municipalities was marred by violence in which at least six people died.

The dominant member in the ruling three-party coalition, the communist United Marxist-Leninist (UML) party, had won more than 34,000 places against the RPP's 9,000 seats in the first round of voting. Officials have ordered re-polls in 437 places affected by violence, and full results are expected this week.

"This campaign of intimidation, threats and strong-arm tactics of the UML sustained by the help of the administration, found the RPP a silent spectator, helpless and without any defence," Lohani said in a statement.
